title: Three anti-social skills to improve your writing - Nadia Kalman

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Start pretending the characters are real

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to decide on the character's actions

options.label: D
options.text: It helps to choose the character's dialogue partner

options.label: B
options.text: When the words and actions don't match

options.label: C
options.text: When the character is speaking formally

options.label: D
options.text: When the character is speaking informally

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

title: Would you weigh less in an elevator? - Carol Hedden

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because the scale doesn't push up as hard.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the elevator is moving downward.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary force responsible for pulling the elevator down?

options.label: D
options.text: It would move at a constant velocity.

options.label: C

title: How Caffeine Works

multiple-choice.question: What type of stimulant is caffeine, and how does it affect the central nervous system?

options.label: A
options.text: Caffeine is a depressant that slows down the central nervous system.

options.label: B
options.text: Caffeine is a stimulant that acts on the peripheral nervous system.

options.label: C
options.text: Caffeine is a stimulant that acts on the central nervous system.

options.label: D
options.text: Caffeine is a hallucinogen that alters perception.

multiple-choice.question: How does caffeine pass through the blood-brain barrier?

options.label: A
options.text: Caffeine is only lipid-soluble, allowing it to pass through the blood-brain barrier.

options.label: B
options.text: Caffeine is only water-soluble, allowing it to pass through the blood-brain barrier.

options.label: C
options.text: Caffeine is both lipid and water-soluble, allowing it to pass through the blood-brain barrier.

options.label: D
options.text: Caffeine cannot pass through the blood-brain barrier.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of adenosine in the nervous system?

options.label: A
options.text: Adenosine acts as a stimulator for the nervous system.

options.label: B
options.text: Adenosine acts as a suppressor for the nervous system.

options.label: C
options.text: Adenosine has no effect on the nervous system.

options.label: D
options.text: Adenosine is a neurotransmitter involved in the fight-or-flight response.

multiple-choice.question: How does caffeine interact with adenosine receptors?

options.label: A
options.text: Caffeine binds to adenosine receptors and activates them.

options.label: B
options.text: Caffeine competes with adenosine for binding to the same receptors, inhibiting adenosine's effects.

options.label: C
options.text: Caffeine has no effect on adenosine receptors.

multiple-choice.question: What hormone is involved in the fight-or-flight response and is stimulated by caffeine?
What is the effect of adrenaline on the body?

options.label: A
options.text: Adrenaline causes a decrease in heart rate and blood pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: Adrenaline causes an increase in heart rate, blood flow to muscles, and blood pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: Adrenaline has no effect on the body.

options.label: D
options.text: Adrenaline causes a decrease in blood sugar levels.

multiple-choice.question: How does caffeine affect dopamine levels in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Caffeine decreases dopamine levels by increasing its reabsorption.

options.label: B
options.text: Caffeine increases dopamine levels by slowing down its reabsorption.

options.label: C
options.text: Caffeine has no effect on dopamine levels.

multiple-choice.question: What is the average half-life of caffeine in the human body?
What is the lethal dose of caffeine per kilogram of body weight?
What would eventually kill a person who consumes a lethal dose of caffeine?

multiple-choice.question: What was unique about the year of the first presidential election in the United States?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: They were afraid of voter fraud.

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.text: To protect citizens from unreasonable searches and seizures

options.label: A
options.text: To guarantee the right to bear arms

options.label: B
options.text: To protect citizens from unreasonable searches and seizures

options.label: D
options.text: To establish that rights not listed in the Bill of Rights are retained by the people and the states

multiple-choice.question: Why are the Ninth and Tenth Amendments often referred to as the "non-rights" amendments?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because they only apply to the states

title: A glimpse of teenage life in ancient Rome - Ray Laurence

multiple-choice.question: What was the Liberalia festival in ancient Rome?

options.label: B
options.text: A festival to honor the gods of war

options.label: C
options.text: An annual festival that celebrates the liberty of Rome's citizens

options.label: D
options.text: A celebration of the Roman Empire's military victories

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: It marked the end of his education

options.label: C
options.text: It was a significant milestone because half of the children in ancient Rome died before reaching adulthood

options.label: D

title: Why do wings help you fly?

multiple-choice.question: What is the traditional explanation for how a wing generates lift?

options.label: B
options.text: Due to its characteristic shape, causing air to travel faster over the top of the wing

multiple-choice.question: According to Bernoulli's principle, what is true about air pressure?

options.label: A
options.text: Faster flowing air exerts more pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Slower flowing air exerts less pressure

options.label: C
options.text: Faster flowing air exerts less pressure

multiple-choice.question: What is a problem with the traditional explanation for lift, as mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It doesn't account for air resistance

options.label: B
options.text: It doesn't explain how a plane can fly upside down

options.label: C
options.text: It doesn't consider the weight of the plane

options.label: D
options.text: It doesn't factor in the speed of the plane

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the air over the top of the wing, according to experiments?

options.label: A
options.text: It travels the same speed as the air underneath

options.label: B
options.text: It travels slower than the air underneath

options.label: C
options.text: It reaches the trailing edge at the same time as the air underneath

options.label: D
options.text: It reaches the trailing edge first

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to a wing generating lift, according to the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: The wing must deflect air downwards

multiple-choice.question: What is the Coanda effect, as mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The tendency of air to separate from a surface

options.label: B
options.text: The tendency of air to stick to a surface and follow its curvature

options.label: C
options.text: The tendency of air to slow down over a surface

options.label: D
options.text: The tendency of air to speed up over a surface

multiple-choice.question: According to Newton's Third Law of Motion, what happens when the wing deflects air downwards?

options.label: A
options.text: The air pushes the wing down

options.label: B
options.text: The air pushes the wing up and back

options.label: C
options.text: The air has no effect on the wing

options.label: D
options.text: The wing pushes the air up

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the Bernoulli explanation and the Newtonian explanation for lift?

options.label: B
options.text: The Bernoulli explanation is completely wrong

options.label: D
options.text: They are two different ways of looking at the same thing

multiple-choice.question: What is a misconception about the traditional explanation for lift, as mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: That air over and under the wing must reconnect at the trailing edge

options.label: B
options.text: That air over the top of the wing goes faster than air beneath

options.label: C
options.text: That the wing must be flat

options.label: D
options.text: That the wing must be symmetrical

title: How does digestion work?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of enzymes in the digestive system?

options.label: B
options.text: To absorb nutrients into the blood

options.label: C
options.text: To catalyze digestive reactions to break down food molecules

multiple-choice.question: Where are digestive enzymes produced in the body?

options.label: C
options.text: In specialized cells in glands and the lining of the gut

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of amylase in the digestive system?

options.label: A
options.text: To break down proteins into amino acids

options.label: B
options.text: To break down lipids into fatty acids and glycerol

options.label: C
options.text: To break down starch into sugars

options.label: D
options.text: To break down nucleic acids into nucleotides

multiple-choice.question: Which enzyme is produced in the stomach, pancreas, and small intestine?
What is the function of lipase in the digestive system?

options.label: A
options.text: To break down carbohydrates into sugars

options.label: B
options.text: To break down proteins into amino acids

options.label: C
options.text: To break down lipids into fatty acids and glycerol

options.label: D
options.text: To break down nucleic acids into nucleotides

multiple-choice.question: Why does the stomach produce hydrochloric acid?

options.label: B
options.text: To begin digestion and kill harmful microorganisms

options.label: D
options.text: To absorb nutrients into the blood

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of bile in the digestive system?

options.label: B
options.text: To neutralize stomach acid and create alkaline conditions

options.label: C
options.text: To absorb nutrients into the blood

options.label: D
options.text: To break down proteins into amino acids

multiple-choice.question: Where is bile produced and stored in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: In the pancreas and small intestine

options.label: C
options.text: In the stomach and small intestine

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the digestion of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats in the small intestine?

options.label: A
options.text: The production of glucose, amino acids, and fatty acids

options.label: B
options.text: The production of nucleic acids, proteins, and lipids

options.label: C
options.text: The production of digestive enzymes and bile

options.label: D
options.text: The absorption of nutrients into the blood

multiple-choice.question: How do the products of digestion in the small intestine enter the bloodstream?

options.label: A
options.text: Through the action of digestive enzymes

options.label: B
options.text: Through the absorption of nutrients into the lymphatic system

options.label: C
options.text: Through diffusion through the lining of the gut

title: What is a fungus?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary way that fungi obtain nutrients?

options.label: A
options.text: By making their own organic carbon-based compounds

options.label: B
options.text: By consuming them from their environment

options.label: C
options.text: By releasing enzymes into the air

options.text: By using sunlight to synthesize nutrients

options.label: A

options.label: B

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the relationship between fungi and plants where they exchange nutrients?

options.label: A
options.text: To absorb nutrients from the environment

options.text: To release enzymes into the environment

title: Gerrymandering: How drawing jagged lines can impact an election - Christina Greer

multiple-choice.question: What is gerrymandering in the context of politics?

options.label: A
options.text: The process of dividing a state into equal districts

options.label: B
options.text: The process of giving one political party an advantage over another by redrawing district lines

options.label: C
options.text: The process of electing a new governor

options.label: D
options.text: The process of creating a new political party

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with originating the concept of gerrymandering in 1812?

options.label: B
options.text: Elbridge Gerry, the governor of Massachusetts

options.label: C
options.text: A member of the Democratic-Republican party

options.label: D
options.text: A journalist from the Boston Gazette

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the party that Elbridge Gerry supported and wanted to give an advantage to through redistricting?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the opponent's voter strength and influence

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease the opponent's voter strength and influence

options.label: C
options.text: To create a new voting bloc

What is a voting bloc in the context of gerrymandering?

options.label: B
options.text: A group of people who would generally vote for one type of party

options.label: C
options.text: A group of people who do not vote

options.label: D
options.text: A group of people who are undecided

multiple-choice.question: Why would a party choose to pack their opponent's districts rather than crack them?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the opponent's voter strength and influence

options.label: B
options.text: To dilute the opponent's voters and gain an advantage

options.label: C
options.text: To create a new voting bloc

multiple-choice.question: How often do politicians typically redraw district lines?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents a fair and equal district

options.label: B
options.text: It represents a district that has been gerrymandered to favor one party

options.label: D
options.text: It represents a politician who supports gerrymandering

title: Diagnosing a zombie: brain and behavior (Part two) - Tim Verstynen & Bradley Voytek

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary challenge in understanding emotions like anger, according to Doctor 2?

options.label: A
options.text: There is a lack of brain imaging studies on the topic.

options.label: B
options.text: Brain imaging studies are mostly correlational.

options.label: C
options.text: The amygdala is a complex brain structure.

options.label: D
options.text: Emotions are not linked to specific brain regions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of studying people with brain lesions in neuroscience, according to Doctor 2?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the effects of brain damage on behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: To identify the brain regions involved in specific behaviors.

options.label: C
options.text: To develop new treatments for neurological disorders.

options.label: D
options.text: To add causal evidence that a brain area might be required for a behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of stimulating the amygdala in cats in the 1950s, according to Doctor 2?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a decrease in aggressive behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to an increase in predatory behaviors.

options.label: C
options.text: It had no effect on behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: It led to a decrease in emotional responses.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Papez circuit, according to Doctor 1?

options.label: A
options.text: A system that links emotion and memory together.

options.label: B
options.text: A brain region involved in aggressive behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the hippocampus, according to Doctor 1?

options.label: B
options.text: To turn short-term memories into long-term memories.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of removing both hippocampuses in Patient H.M., according to Doctor 2?

options.label: C
options.text: He couldn't remember any new information for longer than a few minutes.

options.label: D
options.text: He experienced no changes in behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What is the proposed link between the amygdala and hippocampus, according to Doctor 1?

options.label: C
options.text: The amygdala and hippocampus are physically connected.

options.label: D
options.text: The amygdala and hippocampus are not connected.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential explanation for the zombie's aggression and memory problems, according to Doctor 2?

options.label: A
options.text: Abnormalities in the amygdala and hippocampus.

options.label: C
options.text: Abnormalities in the brain's reward system.

options.label: D
options.text: Abnormalities in the brain's motor control system.

multiple-choice.question: Why does Doctor 1 caution against assuming a link between brain regions and behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: Because brain regions are complex and multifaceted.

options.label: B
options.text: Because correlation does not imply causation.

options.label: C
options.text: Because brain regions are not well understood.

options.label: D
options.text: Because behavior is influenced by multiple factors.

multiple-choice.question: What is the proposed next step in testing the hypothesis about the zombie's aggression and memory problems, according to Doctor 1?

options.label: A
options.text: To conduct more brain imaging studies.

options.label: C
options.text: To gather more data on the zombie's behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: To develop a new treatment for the zombie's condition.

title: The Making of the American Constitution - Judy Walton

multiple-choice.question: In what year did the Revolutionary War end, six years prior to the grand Convention in Philadelphia?

options.label: C
options.text: To draft revisions to the Articles of Confederation

options.text: To address uprisings in the country

options.label: B
options.text: White males, property owners, average age 44

options.label: C
options.text: Men and women, property owners, average age 44

options.label: B

title: The city of walls: Constantinople - Lars Brownworth

multiple-choice.question: Where are the most important walls in Western history located?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of its strategic location for trade

options.label: B
options.text: Because of its cultural and economic stability

options.label: C
options.text: Because of its proximity to the Emperor's birthplace

options.label: A
options.text: To provide shelter from enemy fire

options.label: B
options.text: To allow archers to fire at enemy soldiers trying to swim across the moat

options.label: C
options.text: To block the view of enemy soldiers

options.label: D
options.text: To create a barrier between the moat and the outer wall

options.label: A
options.text: A type of poison used to kill enemy soldiers, applied to the tips of arrows

options.label: B
options.text: An ancient form of napalm that ignited on contact and couldn't be extinguished by water, used in flame throwers and catapults

options.label: C
options.text: A type of explosive used to destroy enemy catapults

options.label: D
options.text: A type of gas used to disorient enemy soldiers

options.label: A
options.text: They tried to breach the walls with catapults, but were unsuccessful

options.label: B
options.text: They tried to tunnel under the walls, but found the foundations too solid

options.label: C
options.text: They tried to starve the city into submission, but ran out of food themselves and had to resort to cannibalism

options.label: D
options.text: They tried to bribe the Roman defenders, but were unsuccessful

options.label: C
options.text: A monster cannon that could fire a 1500-pound stone ball over a mile

multiple-choice.question: What was the final act of the last Roman Emperor, Constantine the 11th?

options.label: B
options.text: He fled the city with his troops

options.label: C
options.text: He drew his sword and jumped into the gap in the wall to stop the onrushing horde

options.label: D
options.text: He negotiated a peace treaty with the Turks

multiple-choice.question: What was the lasting legacy of the walls of Constantinople?

options.text: They preserved the Roman Empire for another century

options.label: B
options.text: They allowed the city to remain independent for another century

options.label: C
options.text: They protected the classical knowledge and traditions that were later transmitted to Western Europe, sparking the Renaissance

options.label: D
options.text: They served as a model for future defensive fortifications
